channel.title: Xiang Li's Blog
channel.description: Recent content on Xiang Li's Blog

item.title: Dan Dan's relocation story
item.description: Merry Christmas from Dan Dan to everyone!

item.title: What I have learned from being a Data Scientist Intern
item.description: Time flies. My ten-weeks summer internship just ended last week, and now may be a good time for me to reflect on the journey and summarize what I have learned from this valuable experience.

item.title: Coding challenge learning note - Part 2
item.description: This post is the continuation of the previous one. Topics covered here are: iterables, date, regex, read files, and other miscellaneous items.

item.title: Coding challenge learning note - Part 1
item.description: As I mentioned in the last post, I was doing a 10-days python coding bootcamp at the end of May.

item.title: Research Crumbs: Tail Bound
item.description: The other day I was having the regular meeting with my advisors to discuss a paper, and there were two theorems involving the tail bound that I found very intriguing.

item.title: Some understandings about measure theory
item.description: I remember the times when I searched for measure theory lectures online and got frustrated immediately at the sight of the abstract definition of Borel set, and the times that I could not wrap my head around when I studied the outer measure in the probability class.

item.title: Coding challenge May of 2021
item.description: This post may not be very informative, but I feel compelled to write something to keep the blog updated regularly, otherwise the guilty feeling of not keeping the commitment would haunt me all the time üòê.

item.title: Why the Central Limit Theorem (CLT) is not working?
item.description: If you ever take any statistics classes, regardless of the level, the chances are high that you would come across The Central Limit Theorem1 (CLT).

item.title: Tensorflow2 learning note - Part 2
item.description: In the second part of this Tensorflow2 mini-series, I will write about how to make use of the pre-trained and well-established deep learning models to perform new tasks.

item.title: Tensorflow2 learning note - Part 1
item.description: Recently I have been taking a series of online courses to learn Tensorflow2, simply out of curiosity to know how it works, especially nowadays when almost everyone is talking about AI, deep learning, etc.

item.title: Interpret limit sets
item.description: In the statistics textbooks or papers, one would encounter many theorems and problems that are studying the limiting behavior of a series of random variables.

item.title: Use Python in R
item.description: As a statistician, I use R a lot in my school works and collaboration projects, since R provides almost all the statistical analysis tools I would need in my research, from data wrangling, statistical modeling, simulation, to data visualization.

item.title: Decompose correlation matrix with block structure
item.description: I recently read an interesting paper1 about how to sample from multivariate normal distribution with less computational complexity, and I really like the part where they make use of the block structure of the correlation matrix to conduct the eigen-decomposition.

item.title: Understand slicing in python 3d-arrays
item.description: I was having a hard time understanding the slicing along different axes of a 3d-array in python.

item.title: What happens if toss a fair coin infinite times?
item.description: Suppose we have a fair coin with two faces Head (H) and Tail (T).

item.title: Website Configuration
item.description: The website is powered by Hugo, employing the theme Anatole.

item.title: Troubleshooting List
item.description: 1. conda not found (Anaconda) This error occurs when running conda command on terminal after upgrading MacOS to Catalina.
I am not a dog üê∂. The cutie on the profile picture is my dog bro, DanDan, who is currently living a happy life in a city called ChiFeng.

item.title: Markdown Syntax Guide
item.description: This article offers a sample of basic Markdown syntax that can be used in Hugo content files, also it shows whether basic HTML elements are decorated with CSS in a Hugo theme.

item.title: Rich Content
item.description: Hugo ships with several Built-in Shortcodes for rich content, along with a Privacy Config and a set of Simple Shortcodes that enable static and no-JS versions of various social media embeds.

item.title: Placeholder Text
item.description: Lorem est tota propiore conpellat pectoribus de pectora summo.

item.title: Math Typesetting
item.description: Mathematical notation in a Hugo project can be enabled by using third party JavaScript libraries.

item.title: Emoji Support
item.description: Emoji can be enabled in a Hugo project in a number of ways.

item.title: Guide to Thumbnails in Hugo
item.description: Thumbnails can be enabled easily by setting the thumbnail parameter in the frontmatter to an image such as "images/landscape.
